awd_titl_txt: RII Track 4: Form Finding and Optimization of the Structural Foundations of Mega-Flora
awd_abstract_narration:
Foundation design has stagnated, stuck in technologies developed decades ago. Shallow and deep foundations are energy intensive and disruptive to install, inefficient in their form and shape. Infrastructure modernization critically depends on design and fabrication of systems with robust functionality at a minimum of energy and materials investments. The solution to this lethargy lays in the foundations of Mega-Flora, large trees. These natural foundation systems have been optimized for a minimum of materials while providing resistance to enormous loads. However, there is little understanding to the role large roots play in structural stability. A new generation of foundation systems can be inspired by nature, but the first step to is to study the form and shape of natural foundations. The work of this award includes mapping the form, shape and mechanics of the roots of large trees. This understanding will lead to new design paradigms. A fundamental understanding of the principles underlying the foundations of mega-flora will significantly improve our ability to design foundations that require less resources, better resist hazards, and improve life safety. Society benefits via resilient infrastructure constructed at less cost. Better knowledge of tree roots will aid foresters in conservation of America's priceless Sequoia, Redwood, and Aspen treasures.

Understanding the unique shape and form of the foundation systems of mega-flora that nature seeks is important for biomimetic engineering of new structural foundations. A new generation of anthropogenic foundation systems can be inspired by these natural systems, but the first step to revitalizing of foundation engineering is to study the topology and morphology of natural foundations. We hypothesize that shape analysis and form-finding optimization techniques can be used identify the predominant forms and shapes of the root topologies that nature seeks to optimize structural stability. These optimized shapes and forms can then be used to inspire a new generation of biomimetic foundations. A global database of 1st order roots is coupled with in-situ mapping roots as inputs to Shape Analysis. Form Finding is then used to identify optimal form and shape. This project greatly advances knowledge and understanding across different fields with synergy between engineering and ecology via a fellowship at Princeton University's Form-Finding Laboratory.  The research effort will result in: (1) physical model data; (2) application of geophysics to new problems, (3) new applications of shape analysis, and (4) the first use of form-finding techniques for buried systems. The behavior of foundations inspired by these shapes and mechanics will lead to new design methods. To perform the research, new methods for geotechnical analyses will be derived in the form-finding paradigm. Validation of novel in-situ imaging of buried roots is transferable to other problems of ecology and geology, as is adaptation of shape analysis for 1st order root structure optimization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award into the form, function, and load carrying capacity of the macro roots of large trees resulted in new knowledge and understanding of the morphology and geometry of large tree root structures, significant new insights into the soil-structure interaction between roots and the ground and demonstrated the importance of careful study of low-stress soil mechanics. Ultimately, the form optimization modeling techniques that were proposed for this award were unsuccessful, but the failure of that approach introduced valuable novel contributions to the engineering literature and our understanding of tension and moment-controlled structures. Form-optimization proved to be overly simplified for the complexity of these natural systems. But, by studying that complexity, the geometric rules of life began to emerge that contribute to the successful load carrying capacity of large trees.

In terms of the form and morphology of the macro roots of large trees, this award enabled the exhumation and mapping of multiple large root systems of Pinus ponderosa in the Black Hills of South Dakota and Wyoming. In comparison with databases of other mapping by others on 30 different species of large tree root systems from around the world, a consistent replicable geometry model emerged. Knowing that nature has infinite variety and that each organism will be site-specific to the exact micro-environment, this consistent geometry appears to be adaptable to all species examined and has  success in forecasting what they macro root system is. This system relied heavily on  known natural mathematical rules such as the golden and silver ratios.

In terms of the load carrying capacity of the macro roots of large trees, this award provided resources for structural testing of macro roots of large trees. Other studies have focused on 3- to 8-year-old juvenile trees. This work focused on mature trees with heights greater than 15-m. Pull-out tests in the field accompanied by strength, density and local stress state measurements showed that root expansion during growth induces large, localized increases in mean normal stress that engage much more soil-structure interaction capacity than theoretically available even adjusted for element roughness. Laboratory studies confirmed these field observations. Further laboratory studies developed a bio-mimetic structural element that has up to 700x more pull-out capacity than base systems. This will enable further development of anthropogenic structures.

In terms of the low-stress soil mechanics and the influence of those mechanical principles on the performance and function of the macro roots of large trees, this award highlighted the need for understanding mathematically the mechanics of geomaterials in the upper 2-m below ground surface. With most of soil mechanics well calibrated to stress levels of 100-kPa or more, the typical and simplified mechanical constitutive relationships were shown in this work to under-perform at stresses less than 50-kPa. Conventional linear Mohr-Coulomb failure envelopes and constitutive models significantly under-performed compared to experiments at the stresses of the upper 2-m, where large roots are located. However, non-linear power-law models were quite successful in representing measured and inferred behaviors, especially when the increase of local stress states of root expansion are incorporated. By careful examination of apparent versus true cohesion, the capacity and capabilities of non-linear power-law models for soil strength at states of 100-kPa and less were demonstrated. Bio-mimetic systems were shown to require both form, geometry and morphology of large root systems, but also the influence of bio-polymers from trees, fungi and bacteria on soil strength at low stresses were revealed.

The resources and research of this award enabled significant achievements in Broader Impacts. Firstly, the products of this research enabled for the development and implementation of a workshop on bio-inspired engineering for the annual Black Hills Women in Science two-day event. Over the period of the award, an estimated 2,400 7th and 8th grade girls were hosted at the workshop. Second, the bio-inspired engineering workshop was modified and presented to incoming freshmen engineering students as part of their welcome-to-campus orientation. An estimated 480 incoming freshmen across all engineering disciplines were thus exposed to new ways of seeing engineering through the bio-inspired and bio-mimetic lens. Multiple undergraduate research assistants were able to synergize cutting-edge research with concurrent theoretical lectures in their coursework on soil mechanics, and particularly low-stress soil mechanics. The products of this award translate beyond civil engineering and impact biology and ecology. By development of an experimentally based and theoretically valid understanding of the mechanics of large tree roots on large trees, this work will enable researchers from these fields to better understand the organisms and the organismal role in the ecosystem as well as performance and longevity of these mega-flora in the face of extreme climactic conditions and natural disasters. Lastly, the investigators of this award were able to work with the host institution of Princeton University, access resources for research there unavailable in South Dakota, and increase their research networks.
